title: Introduction to CSS
content: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style HTML elements. It controls layout, colors, fonts, spacing, and responsive design.

Difference between inline, internal, and external CSS?
What are selectors in CSS?

title: CSS Syntax and Selectors
content: CSS syntax consists of a selector and a declaration block. Selectors target HTML elements. Declarations include property and value pairs.
questions: Explain CSS syntax.
Difference between class and ID selectors?
What are pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements?

title: CSS Colors and Backgrounds
content: CSS supports color names, hex, RGB, RGBA, HSL, and HSLA. Backgrounds can use color, images, gradients, repeat, position, and size.
questions: Difference between RGB and RGBA?
How to add a gradient background?
How to position a background image?

title: CSS Text and Fonts
content: CSS controls text using font-family, font-size, font-weight, font-style, text-align, text-decoration, text-transform, letter-spacing, and line-height.
questions: Difference between serif and sans-serif fonts?
How to capitalize text using CSS?
What is the difference between letter-spacing and word-spacing?

title: CSS Box Model
content: All elements in CSS follow the box model: content, padding, border, and margin. box-sizing controls how width and height are calculated.
questions: Explain the CSS box model.
Difference between content-box and border-box?
How to add spacing between elements using margin?

title: CSS Display and Positioning
content: Display determines how elements are rendered: block, inline, inline-block, flex, grid, none. Position controls placement: static, relative, absolute, fixed, sticky.
questions: Difference between block and inline elements?
Explain relative vs absolute positioning.
What does display: none do?

title: CSS Flexbox
content: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout system. Properties include display: flex, flex-direction, justify-content, align-items, align-self, flex-wrap, and gap.
questions: Difference between justify-content and align-items?
How to reverse the flex direction?
What is the use of flex-wrap?

title: CSS Grid
content: CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system. Properties include display: grid, grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows, grid-gap, grid-area, justify-items, and align-items.
questions: Difference between Flexbox and Grid?
How to create a 3x3 grid layout?
Explain grid-template-areas.

title: CSS Pseudo-classes and Pseudo-elements
content: Pseudo-classes define element states (:hover, :focus, :nth-child), pseudo-elements style parts of elements (::before, ::after, ::first-letter).
questions: Difference between pseudo-class and pseudo-element?
How to style every even child?
What does ::before do?

title: CSS Transitions and Animations
content: Transitions create smooth changes for properties. Animations define keyframes and control duration, timing-function, delay, and iteration-count.
questions: Difference between transition and animation?
How to create a hover transition effect?
Explain @keyframes in CSS animations.

title: CSS Transformations
content: CSS transforms include translate, rotate, scale, skew, and matrix. Transforms can be applied in 2D or 3D for visual effects.
questions: Difference between translate and rotate?
How to scale an element on hover?
What is a 3D transform?

title: CSS Media Queries
content: Media queries allow responsive design. Syntax: @media (condition) { CSS rules }. Conditions include max-width, min-width, orientation, and resolution.
questions: How to make a website responsive using media queries?
Difference between max-width and min-width?
How to target landscape and portrait orientations?

title: CSS Variables
content: CSS variables (--var-name) store reusable values. Use var(--var-name) to access. Variables can be global (:root) or scoped to elements.
questions: How to declare and use a CSS variable?
Difference between global and local CSS variables?
Can variables be updated dynamically?

title: CSS Specificity and Inheritance
content: CSS rules are applied based on specificity: inline > ID > class > element. Inheritance allows child elements to take parent properties.
questions: Explain CSS specificity.
Which has higher priority: ID or class?
Do all properties inherit by default?

title: CSS Z-Index and Stacking Context
content: Z-index controls the stacking order of positioned elements. Stacking context determines how elements are layered. Only positioned elements (relative, absolute, fixed, sticky) use z-index.
questions: How does z-index work?
What is stacking context?
Can z-index work on static elements?

title: CSS Best Practices
content: Write clean, maintainable CSS using semantic class names, modular styles, avoid !important, use variables, and leverage Flexbox/Grid for layouts.
questions: Why avoid using !important in CSS?
